head.title: Will Faith Be an Issue for Voters?

hedline.hl1: Will Faith Be an Issue for Voters?

abstract.p: Rabbi Shmuel Bloom letter points out that many of most rigorously observant Orthodox Jews are also engaged with challenges of contemporary life (S)

block.p: Samuel G. Freedman (Op-Ed, Aug. 8) implies that Modern Orthodox Jews alone among the Orthodox see value in engaging with the larger society. In fact, Orthodoxy's more rigorously observant wing -- known as haredim, Hebrew for fervently dedicated to God -- is hardly disengaged from the challenges of contemporary life.

Haredi community activists, academics and business leaders abound, haredi Jews vote in high percentages, and Agudath Israel of America, a group whose constituents include haredim and others, including Joseph I. Lieberman, has long been an advocate for Jews and religious Americans in Congress and the courts.

Samuel G. Freedman (Op-Ed, Aug. 8) implies that Modern Orthodox Jews alone among the Orthodox see value in engaging with the larger society. In fact, Orthodoxy's more rigorously observant wing -- known as haredim, Hebrew for fervently dedicated to God -- is hardly disengaged from the challenges of contemporary life.

Haredi community activists, academics and business leaders abound, haredi Jews vote in high percentages, and Agudath Israel of America, a group whose constituents include haredim and others, including Joseph I. Lieberman, has long been an advocate for Jews and religious Americans in Congress and the courts.

Besides, haredi Jews who choose more insular lives can hardly be faulted for doing what they can to protect themselves from the cultural corruption that Senator Lieberman has so consistently and laudably condemned. (Rabbi) SHMUEL BLOOM Executive Vice President Agudath Israel of America New York, Aug. 9, 2000
